hurt.title: Create a Quiet, Safe Haven
hurt.text: Provide a soft, warm, and secluded area where your cat can rest undisturbed, away from noise and high traffic areas.

hurt.title: Consult on Pain Management
hurt.text: Discuss with your veterinarian the use of pain medications or supplements suitable for cats, considering any renal or hepatic sensitivities.

hurt.title: Gentle Handling
hurt.text: Handle your cat gently, avoiding pressure on sensitive areas to minimize discomfort.

hurt.title: Thermal Comfort
hurt.text: Use warm compresses or a heated blanket approved for pets to provide comfort, particularly for arthritic joints, but always monitor the temperature to avoid burns.

hurt.title: Restrict High-Impact Activities
hurt.text: Reduce jumping or climbing activities by providing steps or ramps to their favorite spots to prevent strain.

hunger.title: Warm the Food
hunger.text: Gently warming food can increase its aroma and palatability for cats. Always check the temperature to ensure it's just warm, not hot.

hunger.title: Small, Frequent Meals
hunger.text: Offer smaller portions more frequently, which can be easier on your cat’s digestion and more appealing.

hunger.title: Variety is Key
hunger.text: Introduce a variety of textures and flavors, including pâté-style wet food, which may be easier for cats with dental issues or reduced appetite to consume.

hunger.title: Tranquil Eating Environment
hunger.text: Ensure the feeding area is calm and away from loud noises to help your cat relax during meals.

hunger.title: Encourage Hydration
hunger.text: Place water bowls in various comfortable and quiet locations. Consider a cat water fountain to attract your cat to drink more, as the movement of water can be enticing.

hunger.title: Use a Flat Dish for Easier Food Access
hunger.text: Some cat find bowls intimidating or uncomfortable to eat from. A flat dish can make food more accessible and inviting.

hunger.title: Offer Food in Small Amounts at Regular Intervals
hunger.text: Consistent, small portions can help manage your cat's intake without overwhelming them, making meals more manageable.

hunger.title: Ensure Easy Access to Fresh Water at All Times
hunger.text: Dehydration can affect appetite. Making sure your cat has constant access to water is essential for their overall health and can improve eating habits.

hydration.title: Maintain Fresh Water
hydration.text: Change water frequently and use wide, shallow bowls to make it easier for your cat to drink without whisker fatigue.

hydration.title: Flavor the Water
hydration.text: Adding a small amount of flavor, such as chicken or tuna water (always ensure it's free from salt and additives), can entice your cat to drink more.

hydration.title: Incorporate Wet Food
hydration.text: Increase your cat’s moisture intake by incorporating a higher proportion of wet food into their diet.

hydration.title: Ice Cubes as Treats
hydration.text: Offer ice cubes with a hint of flavor or small frozen treats if your cat shows interest, as some cats enjoy playing with or licking ice.

hydration.title: Watch for Signs of Dehydration
hydration.text: Be vigilant for symptoms like dry gums or reduced elasticity in the skin, and consult your veterinarian if these signs appear.

hygiene.title: Regular Brushing
hygiene.text: Maintain your cat's coat by gentle brushing to reduce matting and remove dirt, especially for long-haired breeds.

hygiene.title: Use of Grooming Wipes
hygiene.text: Employ cat-friendly grooming wipes to clean your cat, particularly if they are less able to groom themselves.

hygiene.title: Oral Hygiene Maintenance
hygiene.text: Regular dental care is crucial. Use feline toothbrushes and toothpaste to maintain oral health and prevent diseases that can affect overall well-being.

hygiene.title: Assistance with Grooming
hygiene.text: Help your cat with cleaning after using the litter box if they are unable to do so themselves to prevent irritation or infection.

hygiene.title: Clean and Dry Bedding
hygiene.text: Ensure that bedding is frequently changed to keep the sleeping area clean and dry, reducing the risk of skin infections.

happiness.title: Recognize Preferred Stimuli
happiness.text: Observe and reintroduce specific toys or activities that have previously engaged your cat, adjusting for any physical limitations they might now have.

happiness.title: Increase Companion Time
happiness.text: Spend quiet, quality time with your cat, providing gentle petting or simply sitting together, to enhance their emotional well-being.

happiness.title: Introduce New Gentle Activities
happiness.text: Offer new forms of mental stimulation such as puzzle feeders or window perches to help keep their environment engaging.

happiness.title: Encourage Gentle Socialization
happiness.text: Allow your cat to interact with other familiar pets if they show interest, but ensure these interactions are controlled and stress-free.

happiness.title: Comforting Items
happiness.text: Provide familiar and comforting items like their favorite blanket or a piece of your clothing to help them feel secure.

happiness.title: Soothing Sounds
happiness.text: Play soft, calming music or utilize white noise to help soothe your cat, which can be particularly beneficial for those sensitive to loud or unfamiliar sounds.

happiness.title: Consult a Vet
happiness.text: If your cat’s mood does not improve, consult a veterinarian to rule out underlying health issues that might be affecting their mood or comfort.

mobility.title: Encourage Light Activity
mobility.text: Promote gentle movement through light play with soft toys to maintain muscle tone and joint health without excessive strain.

mobility.title: Orthopedic Support
mobility.text: Provide an orthopedic or heated cat bed to support joints and offer comfort, which can be especially helpful for cats with arthritis.

mobility.title: Therapeutic Massage
mobility.text: Gently massage your cat’s limbs to enhance circulation and reduce discomfort, particularly before and after periods of rest.

mobility.title: Safe Play Options
mobility.text: Introduce low-impact toys that encourage activity without requiring vigorous movement, such as toys that can be batted or small automated toys.

mobility.title: Professional Physical Therapy
mobility.text: Consider consulting with a veterinary physical therapist who can tailor exercises to your cat’s specific needs to enhance mobility.

mobility.title: Adapt Home Environment
mobility.text: Make your home more accessible for your cat by adding steps to furniture or a ramp to their favorite window sill.

mobility.title: Optimal Weight Management
mobility.text: Monitor your cat’s diet closely to maintain a healthy weight, thereby reducing stress on their joints and facilitating easier movement.

mobility.title: Mobility Aids Consideration
mobility.text: For cats with significant mobility challenges, discuss with your veterinarian the possibility of mobility aids like supportive slings or wheelchairs designed for cats.

encouragement.title: Scent Enrichment Activities
encouragement.text: Introduce natural scents that can intrigue and comfort your cat without overwhelming them. Examples include dried catnip, valerian root, or familiar scents like a blanket with their scent or yours.

encouragement.title: Introduce New Toys
encouragement.text: Offer new, stimulating toys that cater to a cat’s hunting instincts or provide gentle interaction.

encouragement.title: Extended Cuddle Time
encouragement.text: Spend extra time cuddling your cat on good days, using soft blankets or your lap as a cozy spot.

encouragement.title: Sunbathing Areas
encouragement.text: Set up a comfortable, warm spot near a window where your cat can bask in the sunlight. Ensure that the area is safe and easily accessible.

encouragement.title: Document Joyful Days
encouragement.text: Maintain a journal dedicated to the joyful days spent with your cat, noting details that brought you both happiness.

encouragement.title: Organize a Mini Photo Shoot
encouragement.text: Set up a calm photo session at home with minimal props to capture your cat’s natural demeanor.

encouragement.title: Interactive Food Puzzles
encouragement.text: Use simple food puzzles that do not require much effort to solve. These can be as straightforward as hiding small amounts of food in easy-to-reach places to encourage some light activity and mental engagement.

encouragement.title: Gentle Grooming Sessions
encouragement.text: Regular, gentle grooming sessions can help maintain your cat’s coat and skin health while providing a soothing interaction between you and your pet.

encouragement.title: Storytime
encouragement.text: Read aloud to your cat from a comfortable spot, letting them relax to the sound of your voice.

encouragement.title: Happy Moments Box
encouragement.text: Start a collection box of mementos from special days, like feathers from toys or snippets from your cat’s favorite blanket.

encouragement.title: Special Treat Preparation
encouragement.text: Prepare a cat-safe treat on particularly good days, something delicious and healthy.

encouragement.title: Comfort Zones
encouragement.text: Create multiple small comfort zones around your home with favorite blankets, pillows, or even a heated pet bed. Each zone should be easily accessible and placed in quiet corners or familiar areas.

encouragement.title: Have a Relaxing Spa Day
encouragement.text: Offer a gentle grooming session, including brushing and maybe a soothing wipe-down.

assessments.hurtInfo: Is {{petName}} painfree? Or can {{petName}}’s pain be successfully managed?

hurtOptions.title: Severe Pain
hurtOptions.description: {{petName}} shows clear signs of pain, such as hissing or growling when touched, reluctance to move, and inability to find a comfortable resting position.

hurtOptions.title: Moderate Pain
hurtOptions.description: Visible discomfort during movements or when being petted in certain areas, may have reduced grooming.

hurtOptions.title: Mild Pain
hurtOptions.description: {{petName}} seems slightly uncomfortable, may avoid jumping or high activity, but can still use the litter box and rest without significant issues.

hurtOptions.title: Occasional Discomfort
hurtOptions.description: Rare signs of discomfort, such as hesitance jumping onto high surfaces or mild stiffness after rest.

hurtOptions.title: Pain-Free
hurtOptions.description: {{petName}} is agile and shows no signs of discomfort. Able to jump and climb as usual.

hungerOptions.title: Refuses to Eat
hungerOptions.description: {{petName}} won't eat anything, ncluding favorite treats and especially dry food, showing a complete loss of appetite.

hungerOptions.title: Struggles to Eat
hungerOptions.description: Shows interest in food but struggles to eat without assistance; may only lick juice or gravy.

hungerOptions.title: Eats with Encouragement
hungerOptions.description: Requires encouragement or prefers highly palatable food, may eat slower than usual.

hungerOptions.title: Eats with Minor Issues
hungerOptions.description: Eats slightly less than usual or shows a preference for softer foods.

hungerOptions.title: Eats Normally
hungerOptions.description: {{petName}} egular meals without hesitation, including dry and wet food.

hydrationOptions.title: Refuses to Drink
hydrationOptions.description: Won't drink any water, showing possible dehydration signs like lethargy, dry gums.

hydrationOptions.title: Needs Assistance to Drink
hydrationOptions.description: Shows interest in water but may need encouragement like being brought to the water or gentle stroking while drinking.

hydrationOptions.title: Drinks a Little
hydrationOptions.description: Drinks less than usual, may need water to be placed near resting areas or prefers certain types of bowls or locations.

hydrationOptions.title: Drinks with Encouragement
hydrationOptions.description: Prefers running water or may only drink when fresh water is provided, might be more enticed by water with a bit of flavor.

hydrationOptions.title: Hydrated and Healthy
hydrationOptions.description: Regularly drinks water from bowls or fountains, showing no signs of dehydration.

assessments.hygieneInfo: Is {{petName}} clean and comfortable? Is {{petName}} able to keep himself clean?

hygieneOptions.title: Severely Unkempt
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} regularly soils themselves, does not use litter box properly, fur may become matted and dirty, indicating severe decline.

hygieneOptions.title: Needs Frequent Help
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} needs help grooming hard-to-reach areas, may begin to neglect fur cleaning, increased risk of dermatitis or matting.

hygieneOptions.title: Occasionally Messy
hygieneOptions.description: Requires occasional help with grooming, especially if arthritic or weak, may have minor accidents.

hygieneOptions.title: Generally Clean
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} mostly self-grooms but might not reach all areas, might avoid the litter box if not clean but generally manages well.

hygieneOptions.title: Always Clean
hygieneOptions.description: {{petName}} maintains good grooming habits, fur remains clean and sleek, uses litter box effectively.

assessments.happinessInfo: Does {{petName}} express joy and interest? Is {{petName}} responsive to things around him (family, toys, etc)?

happinessOptions.title: Severely Depressed
happinessOptions.description: Disinterested in all forms of interaction, shows no response to toys or family, may hide or sleep excessively.

happinessOptions.title: Often Uninterested
happinessOptions.description: Infrequently interacts or plays, shows little interest in surroundings, may withdraw from family activities.

happinessOptions.title: Mildly Interested
happinessOptions.description: Occasionally engages in play or seeks attention, prefers quieter activities, may spend more time resting.

happinessOptions.title: Generally Happy
happinessOptions.description: Still engages with family and may play with toys, but may be less active or show mild signs of withdrawal.

happinessOptions.title: Fully Joyful
happinessOptions.description: {{petName}} shows usual curiosity and playfulness, actively seeks out family for interaction and plays with favorite toys.

assessments.mobilityInfo: Can {{petName}} get up without assistance? Can {{petName}} access their favorite spots?

mobilityOptions.title: Immobile
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} requires assistance for all movement, may be unable to reach litter box or food without help.

mobilityOptions.title: Severely Limited
mobilityOptions.description: Limited movement, may need assistance to reach litter box or feeding areas, avoids previous activities.

mobilityOptions.title: Moderately Limited
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} shows some difficulty with movement, may avoid stairs or no longer jump, moves slower.

mobilityOptions.title: Slightly Limited
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} is mostly independent but may hesitate at higher jumps or need a little help climbing onto favored perches.

mobilityOptions.title: Fully Mobile
mobilityOptions.description: {{petName}} moves with ease throughout the house, jumps and climbs without hesitation.
